description: From Middle English sheltron, sheldtrume (“roof or wall formed by locked shields”), from Old English sċildtruma, sċyldtruma (“a phalanx, company (of troops), a tortoise, a covering, shed, shelter”, literally “shield-troop”), from sċyld, sċield (“shield”) + truma (“a troop of soldiers”). Cognate with Scots schilthrum, schiltrum. More at shield, and Old English trymman (“to strengthen”), from trum (“strong, firm”) at trim.

entries.meaning: A refuge, haven or other cover or protection from something.
An institution that provides temporary housing for homeless people, battered women, etc.

verbs.description: shelter (third-person singular simple present shelters, present participle sheltering, simple past and past participle sheltered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To provide cover from damage or harassment; to shield; to protect.
examples: Those ruins sheltered once his sacred head.
During the rainstorm, we sheltered under a tree.
